GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 32.001  DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



   CITY.  The city of Pinckneyville.



   EMPLOYEE.  Any person, other than an officer, who is hired to perform
work for the city at a fixed wage or salary or other measure of compensation.



   OFFICER.  Any person who is elected or appointed to an office created
by the Illinois Municipal Code or any ordinance of the city.



   PROPERTY OF THE CITY.  Land or personal property of the city located
within or outside its corporate limits.



   (B)   Any reference to a city department includes all equipment,
buildings, apparatus, systems, facilities, machinery or other real and
personal property used or occupied by the department in the course of its
particular function or service.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.002  PURCHASING.



   Subject to the limitations prescribed in § 30.03 and the Illinois
Municipal Code, the Superintendents of the departments of Public Affairs,
Accounts and Finances, Public Health and Safety, Streets and Public
Improvements, Public Property, shall purchase all the supplies and materials
and arrange on contract for all the labor necessary to effect the
construction, maintenance and repair of the public buildings, property, land,
systems and facilities under his or her supervision or to carry out the
duties assigned by this chapter.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.003  EXCHANGE OF PERSONNEL.



   In order to utilize the work force of the city to the greatest
advantage to the city, each Commissioner shall cooperate with the other in
the exchange and assignment of officers and employees and in cases where the
mayor deems and emergency to exist, the Mayor shall have the power to assign
all officers and employees of the city to the work or activities as he or she
deems appropriate in the emergency.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.004  PREPARATION OF ANNUAL APPROPRIATIONS ORDINANCE.



   The Mayor and each Commissioner shall cooperate in the preparation of
the annual appropriation ordinance and recommend to the City Council the
items and amounts of the appropriations required by their respective
departments for the fiscal year covered by the ordinance.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.005  PART-TIME POLICE.



   (A)   Employment.  The city may employ part-time police officers
from time to time as it deems necessary.



   (B)   Duties.  A part-time police officer shall have all the
responsibilities of a full-time police officer and such specific duties as
delineated in the General Orders of the Pinckneyville Police Department, but
the number of hours a part-time officer may work within a calendar year is
restricted.  Part-time police officers shall not be assigned to supervise or
direct full-time police officers.  Part-time police officers shall be
trained in accordance with the Illinois Police Training Act, ILCS Ch. 50, Act
705, § 1 et seq., and the rules and requirements of the ILETSB.



   (C)   Hiring standards. Any person employed as a part-time police
officer must meet the following standards:



      (1)   Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of
sound health, and physically and mentally be able to perform the assigned
duties;



      (2)   Be at least 21 years of age;



      (3)   Pass a medical examination;



      (4)   Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate;



      (5)   Possess a valid State of Illinois driver’s license;



      (6)   Possess no prior felony convictions.



      (7)   Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must
have been honorably discharged.



   (D)   Discipline.  Part-time officers shall be under the
disciplinary jurisdiction of the Chief of Police.  Part-time police officers
serve at the discretion of the city authorities, shall not have any property
rights in said employment and may be removed by the city authorities at any
time.  Part-time police officers shall comply with all applicable rules and
General Orders of the Police Department.



(Ord. O-2012-11, passed 12-10-12)



FIRE DEPARTMENT



§ 32.010  DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.



   There is hereby established a department which shall be known as the
Volunteer Fire Department and which shall embrace one Fire Chief, one
Assistant Fire Chief, One Secretary, and one Treasurer, and the members of
the Volunteer Fire Department.



(Ord. 92, passed 4-2-28)



§ 32.011  FIRE CHIEF.



   (A)   Office created; bond required.  There is hereby created the
office of Fire Chief of the Fire Department, who shall be elected annually by
the  members of the Fire Department at the first meeting in May of each
year, and shall enter into bond, in an amount to be determined by Council,
payable to the city, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties
and for the proper care of the property and fire equipment of the Fire
Department and before entering upon his duties, shall subscribe to the oath
as provided in § 32.015.



   (B)   Duties.  It shall be the duty of the Fire Chief to command
the Fire Department on all occasions, and see that all equipment is kept in
good order, that each man performs his duty, and to enforce the rules and
regulations of the Department as provided by ordinance and otherwise. He
shall preside at all meetings, with power to vote on all questions; shall
appoint all committees; shall have power to grant leaves of absence and to
call special meetings of said Department and to place the men when in service
as he may see proper.



(Ord. 92, passed 4-2-28)



§ 32.012  ASSISTANT FIRE CHIEF.



   (A)   Office created.  There is hereby created the office of
Assistant Fire Chief of the Fire Department who shall be elected by the
members of the Fire Department at the first meeting in May of each year.



   (B)   Duties.  The Assistant Fire Chief shall perform such duties
as is herein provided and required of the Fire Chief, in the absence of the
Fire Chief, and shall take and subscribe to the oath as provided in § 32.015.



(Ord. 92, passed 4-2-28)



§ 32.013  SECRETARY.



   (A)   Office created.  There is hereby created the office of
Secretary of the Fire Department who shall be elected by the members of the
Fire Department at the first meeting in May each year.



   (B)   Duties.  The Secretary shall perform the duties usual for a
Secretary of such bodies, such as keep a careful record of all minutes of the
meetings of the Department and all like duties, and shall before entering
upon his duties take and subscribe to the oath in § 32.015.



(Ord. 92, passed 4-2-28)



§ 32.014  TREASURER.



   (A)   Office created.  There is hereby created the office of
Treasurer of the Fire Department.  The Treasurer shall be elected by the
members of the Fire Department at the first meeting in May each year, and
shall hold his office for one year and until his successor is elected and
qualified.



   (B)   Oath; bond.  The Treasurer, before entering upon his duties
shall take and subscribe to the oath provided for in § 32.015, and execute a
bond to the city with sureties to be approved by the Mayor. The penal sum of
the bond shall be equal to twice the amount of funds arising from the fire
insurance tax, in the treasury of the Department at the time the Treasurer
takes office, plus twice the aggregate to be received on account of fire
insurance tax as provided by ordinance as estimated for the ensuing year.



   (C)   Duties.  It shall be the duty of the Treasurer to keep all
money received on account of fire insurance taxes separate and apart from all
funds in his hands. The proceeds of the fire insurance tax shall be paid only
on warrants signed by the Chief and Secretary, and ordered by majority vote
of those present at a regular or special meeting of the Depart- ment. Every
such warrant shall state on its face the purpose for which it is drawn. The
Treasurer shall make an annual report, in detail, of the receipts and
expenditures of the funds arising from such fire department tax, which report
shall be submitted to the City Council on or before the third Monday of April
in each year.



(Ord. 92, passed 4-2-28)



§ 32.015  OATH.



   Each of the officers provided for in this subchapter shall take and
subscribe to the following oath:



      “I do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of
the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois and
faithfully perform the duties of the office  of (name of office) as
prescribed by ordinance and the statutes of the State of Illinois, to the
best of my ability, so help me God.”



and each officer shall serve the term of one year and until their successors
are elected and qualified.



(Ord. 92, passed 4-2-28)



§ 32.016  FEES AND COSTS FOR SERVICES PROVIDED TO NON-RESIDENTS.



   (A)   Whenever the Fire Department provides firefighting or
emergency response services to or for the benefit of any person, business or
other entity that is not a resident of the city, the Fire Chief shall be
authorized to send a statement and collect fees for such services and to send
a statement reimbursement of the cost of any materials or supplies used for
firefighting and emergency response services provided to such persons,
businesses or other entities that are not residents of the city. The charge
for firefighting and emergency response services rendered by the city to
persons, businesses or entities that are not residents of the city shall be
computed at the rate of $250 per hour per vehicle and $70 per hour per
firefighter responding to a call for assistance which the city deems to be an
amount not exceeding the cost to the city for providing such services. An
additional charge may be billed for reimbursement of the expense for
materials or supplies used in rendering such services. No charge shall be
made for services, supplies or materials for which the total statement would
be less than $50. So long as the city and the Pinckneyville Rural Fire
Protection District maintain any verbal or written agreement to provide
mutual aid and assistance for the residents of their respective territories,
the city shall not bill or collect fees for services rendered or
reimbursement for materials provided within the city to or for the benefit of
any person, business or other entity that is a resident of the Pinckneyville
Rural Fire Protection District.



   (B)   In the event a statement issued pursuant to this section is
not paid within 90 days after the date it is issued, the City Attorney is
authorized to take such legal action as may be necessary to secure payment,
including, but not limited to the filing of a civil action.



   (C)   This section does not require billing or collection of fees
for firefighting or emergency response services provided by the city beyond
the corporate limits of the city or to persons, businesses or entities that
are not residents of the city if such services are provided by the city in
accordance with the terms of a mutual aid agreement with another municipality
or fire department.



(Ord. O-2015-16, passed 8-10-15)



DEPARTMENT OF ACCOUNTS AND FINANCES



§ 32.025  COMMISSIONER TO BE SUPERINTENDENT; DUTIES.



   (A)   The duly elected Commissioner of Accounts and Finances shall
be the Superintendent of that department.



   (B)   The Commissioner shall perform the following duties:



      (1)   Require all officers and employees of the city to keep
all records and accounts and to make all reports required by law and to
inspect and examine them;



      (2)   To audit all those records, accounts and reports, as may
be required by law;



      (3)   To publish all reports or accounts required by law;



      (4)   To report promptly to the City Council the failure of
any officer or employee to keep a proper record or account or to make a
report, and to report promptly to the Council any irregularity or unlawful
act with respect to any record, account or report;



      (5)   To examine and report to the Council on all bills,
accounts, payrolls, claims and other charges presented to the Council for
payment;



      (6)   To require all public utility corporations operating
within the city to file all reports required by law or for the lawful
ordinances of the city;



      (7)   To collect all money due and owning the city from any
source;



      (8)   To make provision for the payment of the principal and
interest on all outstanding bonds of the city; and



      (9)   To invest, by and with the advice and consent of the
Council, all funds of the city not required for the immediate payment of its
obligations.



(Ord. 0-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.026  ENTITIES UNDER COMMISSIONER’S SUPERVISION.



   The Commissioner of Accounts and Finances shall have charge of,
supervision and direction over the following officers and municipal functions
and services:



   (A)   City Clerk;



   (B)   City Treasurer;



   (C)   All financial records and accounts of the city; and



   (D)   Care and maintenance of City Hall.



(Ord. 0-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY



§ 32.035  COMMISSIONER TO BE SUPERINTENDENT; DUTIES.



   (A)   The duly elected Commissioner of Public Health and Safety
shall be the Superintendent of that department.



   (B)   The Commissioner shall perform the following duties:



      (1)   Regularly inspect the police and fire fighting
apparatus, equipment and supplies of the city and make recommendations to the
City Council for the repair and replacement thereof;



      (2)   Regulate the hours of work of the personnel of the Fire
Department and Police Depart- ment to achieve the maximum protection of the
lives and property of the citizens and residents of the city;



      (3)   Regularly inspect all public and private buildings, to
the extent authorized by this code of ordinances, for the violations of any
ordinance relating to plumbing, sanitary, heating and electrical facilities
or fire safety regulations;



      (4)   Issue all permits for the construction or repair of any
building or structure in the city, or the installation or repair of plumbing,
sanitary, heating or electrical facilities therein;



      (5)   Regularly inspect the city for the existence of
nuisances or unsanitary conditions and commence the legal action available to
correct or abate the nuisances or unsanitary conditions;



      (6)   Observe traffic conditions in the city and recommend to
the Council regulatory measures deemed necessary to regulate and control the
conditions; and



      (7)   Enforce all ordinances of the city pertaining to the
health and safety of the citizens and residents of the city.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.036  ENTITIES UNDER COMMISSIONER’S SUPERVISION.



   The Commissioner of Public Health and Safety shall have charge of,
supervision and direction over the following officers and municipal functions
and services:



   (A)   Fire Department;



   (B)   Police Department;



   (C)   Building inspections and issuances of permits for construction
and repairs thereof;



   (D)   Board of Health; and



   (E)   Regulation of vehicle traffic.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



DEPARTMENT OF STREETS AND PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS



§ 32.045  COMMISSIONER TO BE SUPERINTENDENT; DUTIES.



   (A)   The duly elected Commissioner of Streets and Public
Improvements shall be the Superintendent of that department.



   (B)   The Commissioner shall have the following duties:



      (1)   Regularly inspect the streets, alleys, bridges and
sidewalks in the city or on lands owned by the city;



      (2)   Prepare or cause to be prepared estimates of the cost of
constructing, repairing and maintaining all the facilities and cooperate with
all state and federal agencies furnishing or allocating funds for the
purposes;



      (3)   Construct, repair and maintain all the streets, alleys,
bridges and sidewalks and, where the work is done with municipal funds and
labor, supervise that work;



      (4)   Provide adequate storm water drainage facilities;



      (5)   Require all public utility corporations furnishing
telephone, light and power services to file all reports required by law and
to observe the terms and provisions of any franchise under which the utility
is operating in the city;



      (6)   Inspect and report any deficiencies in street lighting
facilities and regulate the location of such facilities; and



      (7)   Repair and maintain the roads and public ways in the
city cemetery and provide for grass and weed cutting and control.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.046  ENTITIES UNDER COMMISSIONER’S SUPERVISION.



   The Commissioner of Streets and Public Improvements shall have charge
of, supervision and direction over the following departments, municipal
functions and services, utilities and public property:



   (A)   Street Department;



   (B)   Construction, repair and maintenance of all streets, alleys,
bridges and sidewalks in the city or on land owned by the city;



   (C)   Street lighting;



   (D)   Supervision over the installation and maintenance of
telephone, light and power utility facilities;



   (E)   Issuance of permits for work involving excavations in any
street or alley;



   (F)   Care and maintenance of the city cemetery;



   (G)   Traffic control; and



   (H)   Garbage and refuse collection and disposal.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC PROPERTY



§ 32.055  COMMISSIONER TO BE SUPERINTENDENT; DUTIES.



   (A)   The duly elected Commissioner of Public Property shall be the
Superintendent of that department.



   (B)   The Commissioner shall have the following duties:



      (1)   Regularly inspect all the public buildings under the
Commissioner’s supervision and control and to repair and maintain the same;



      (2)   Supervise and regulate the operation of the municipal
Water Department, Sewer Department, Gas Department and swimming pool; to
supervise all connections thereto and issue permits therefor; and to
recommend to the City Council the rates and charges from time to time to be
charged for the sale and consumption of water, natural gas, and sewer
services;



      (3)   Regularly inspect the water treatment and distribution
system and sewerage collection and disposal system and the gas utility
system; and to repair, maintain and operate the same in accordance with the
ordinances of the city and the regulations of any state or federal agency
having jurisdiction over or regulatory powers with respect to the same;



      (4)   Regularly inspect the city reservoir and appurtenances
and promptly report to the Council any construction or repairs required to
maintain an adequate supply of water for the city and water users;



      (5)   Assist the Commissioner of Accounts and Finances in the
collection of all charges made for the sale of water and the use of the
sewerage system and the sale of natural gas of the city;



      (6)   Inspect, repair and maintain the municipal baseball and
softball fields and supervise the use thereof;



      (7)   Prepare estimates of the cost of the construction,
repair and maintenance of all public property and municipal plants, systems
and facilities under his or her supervision and control; and



      (8)   Regularly inspect and maintain the swimming pool and to
provide for the collection of all charges in connection with the use thereof.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



Cross-reference:



   Use of city-owned property, see § 31.05



§ 32.056  ENTITIES UNDER COMMISSIONER’S SUPERVISION.



   The Commissioner of Public Property shall have charge of, supervision
and direction over the following departments, municipal functions, services,
and public property:



   (A)   The construction, repair and maintenance of all municipal
buildings, except the City Hall Building;



   (B)   Water Department;



   (C)   Sewer Department;



   (D)   City reservoir;



   (E)   Municipal baseball and softball diamonds and appurtenances;



   (F)   All recreational equipment not under the jurisdiction of the
Park Board;



   (G)   Natural gas utility; and



   (H)   Swimming pool.



(Ord. O-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



CEMETERY BOARD OF MANAGERS



§ 32.065  CEMETERY DESIGNATED; BOARD ESTABLISHED.



   (A)   The public graveyard or public cemetery located on the north
side of County Road in the city is hereby designated and hereafter to be
known and called Pinckneyville City Cemetery.



   (B)   The management and control of the cemetery hereby is vested in
a Board of Managers consisting of five persons.  The Board shall have the
care, charge, management and control of the cemetery, under the supervision
of the City Council.



(Ord. O-86-11, passed 11-17-86)



§ 32.066  MEMBERS; TERMS.



   (A)   The term of office of each member of the Board of Managers
shall be four years.



      (1)   The members of the Board shall be appointed by the Mayor
with the advice and consent of the City Council.



      (2)   The members of the Board shall hold office for a term of
four years and until their successors are appointed.  Initially, three
members shall serve for a term of four years and two members shall serve for
a term of two years and thereafter for a term of four years, so the term of
office of all the members of the Board shall not expire at the same time. 
The Mayor, in appointing members of the Board, shall designate those whose
initial term shall be four years and those whose initial term shall be two
years.



   (B)   The Council shall have the power to remove from office any or
all of the Board members or the Treasurer for nonperformance of duties or for
misappropriation or wrongful use of the funds or property and to require a
just and proper accounting for the same.



(Ord. O-86-11, passed 11-17-86)



§ 32.067  OFFICERS.



   The Board of Managers, as soon as may be convenient after appointment,
shall meet and organize by selecting one of their number to be President,
another of their number to be Clerk and another to be Treasurer, who may or
may not be a member of the Board.



   (A)   Treasurer.



      (1)   The person selected as Treasurer, before entering upon
the duties of the office, shall execute a bond to the state for the use of
the Board.  The bond shall be in the penal sum of not less than double the
value of the money or funds coming into his or her hands as Treasurer,
conditioned for the faithful performance of duties and for the faithful
accounting for all money or funds which, by virtue of the office, comes into
his or her possession and to be in the form and with securities as may be
prescribed and approved by the City Council to be approved and preserved in
the same manner as the bond of the City Treasurer.



      (2)   The Treasurer shall have the custody of all money and
property received in trust by the Board and shall pay out the same only upon
the written order of the Board, signed by the President and Clerk.



      (3)   The Treasurer shall keep permanent books and records of
all trust funds and all receipts and disbursements and for what purposes
received and disbursed.



      (4)   The Treasurer annually shall make a written report under
oath to the Board showing balances, receipts and disbursements, including a
statement showing the amount and principal of trust funds on hand and how
invested.  The report shall be audited by the Board and, if found correct,
shall be transmitted to the City Council at the same time the City Treasurer
is required by law to make his or her report to be approved and preserved in
the same manner.



   (B)   The Clerk of the Board shall keep a permanent record of the
proceedings of the Board, signed by the President and attested by the Clerk,
and also shall keep a permanent record of the several trust funds from what
sources received, the amounts thereof and for what uses and purposes,
respectively.



(Ord. O-86-11, passed 11-17-86)



§ 32.068  FINANCES.



   (A)   The Board of Managers is hereby authorized and empowered to
receive and hold in perpetual trust any sum of money or any funds, securities
or property of any kind given, donated or bequeathed for the maintenance,
care, repair, upkeep or ornamentation of the cemetery or any lot or grave in
the cemetery as may be specified in the instrument making the gift, donation
or legacy.



      (1)   The Board shall have the right to convert the property
into money and shall invest the proceeds thereof and the money so given,
donated and bequeathed to it.



      (2)   The principal of the trust fund shall be kept intact and
perpetually invested and the income thereof perpetually shall be applied for
the purposes specified in the instrument making the gift, donation or legacy
and for no other purposes.



      (3)   All instruments shall be only those authorized for the
city by law.



   (B)   The Board also may receive from the city the funds that may be
appropriated by the city for the use of the cemetery.



   (C)   The trust funds, gifts and legacies herein and the income
arising therefrom shall be exempt from taxation and from the operation of all
laws of Mortmain and the laws against perpetuities and accumulations.



   (D)   Any trust executed to the cemetery by its name shall vest in
the Board thereof and take effect to al intents and purposes as if executed
to the Board.



(Ord. O-86-11, passed 11-17-86)



PLAN COMMISSION



§ 32.080  PURPOSE.



   In order that adequate provisions be made for the preparation of a
comprehensive city plan for the guidance, direction and control of the growth
and development or redevelopment of the city and contiguous territory, not
more than 1½ miles beyond the corporate limits and not included in any
municipality, a Plan Commission hereby is created under the authority of the
Illinois Municipal Code, approved May 29, 1961 and effective July 1, 1961,
and as amended.



(Ord. 64-2, passed 7-14-64)



2007 S-10



§ 32.081  MEMBERSHIP.



   The Plan Commission shall consist of seven members, citizens of the
city, appointed by the Mayor, on the basis of their particular fitness for
their duty on the Plan Commission and subject to the approval of the Council.



(Ord. 64-2, passed 7-14-64; Am. Ord. 0-92-17, passed 8-3-92)



§ 32.082  TERMS; COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Terms.  Of the seven members, three shall serve for a period
of three years, two for a period of two years and two for a period of one
year.  There- after, such members shall serve for a period of three years. 



   (B)   Vacancies.  Vacancies shall be filled by appointments for
unexpired terms only. 



   (C)   Compensation.  All members off the Commission shall serve
without compensation, except that, if the Council deems it advisable, they
may receive such compensation as may be fixed from time to time by said
Council and provided for in the annual budget.



(Ord. 64-2, passed 7-14-64; Am. Ord. 0-92-17, passed 8-3-92)



§ 32.083  OFFICERS; RECORDS; REPORTS.



   (A)   Immediately following their appointment, the members of the
Plan Commission shall meet, organize, elect the officers it may deem
necessary and adopt and later change or alter rules and regulations of
organization and procedure consistent with city ordinances and state laws.



      (1)   The Commission shall keep written records of its
proceedings, which shall be open at all times to public inspection.



      (2)   The Commission also may file an annual report with the
Mayor and City Council, setting forth its transactions and recommendations.



   (B)   The City Clerk shall furnish the Plan Commission, for its
consideration, a copy of all ordinances, plans and data relative to public
improvements of any nature.  The Commission may report in relation thereto
if it deems a report is necessary or advisable, for the consideration of the
Council.  (Ord. 64-2, passed 7-14-64)



§ 32.084  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Plan Commission shall have the following powers and duties:



   (A)   To prepare and recommend to the City Council a comprehensive
plan for the present and future development or redevelopment of the city and
contiguous unincorporated territory not more than 1½ miles beyond the
corporate limits of the city and not included in any other municipality.



      (1)   The plan may be adopted in whole or in separate
geographical or functional parts, each of which, when adopted, shall be the
official comprehen- sive plan, or part thereof, of the city.



      (2)   The plan shall be advisory except as to the part that
has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the Council.



      (3)   All requirements for public hearings, filing of notice
of adoption with the County Recorder of Deeds and filing of the plan and
ordinances with the City Clerk shall be complied with as provided for by law.



      (4)   To provide for the health, safety, comfort and
convenience of the inhabitants of the city and contiguous territory, the plan
shall establish reasonable standards of design for subdivisions and for
resubdivisions of unimproved land and of areas subject to redevelopment in
respect to public improvements as herein defined and shall establish
reasonable requirements governing the location, width, course and surfacing
of public streets and highways, alleys, ways for public service facilities,
curbs, gutters, sidewalks, street lights, parks, playgrounds and school
grounds, the size of lots to be used for residential purposes, storm water
drainage, water supply and distribution, sanitary sewers and sewage
collection and treatment.  The requirements specified herein shall become
regulatory only when adopted by ordinance.



   (B)   To designate land suitable for annexation to the city and the
recommended zoning classification for the land upon annexation.



   (C)   To recommend to the City Council, from time to time, the
changes in the comprehensive plan or any part thereof as may be deemed
necessary.



   (D)   To prepare and recommend to the Council, from time to time,
plans and/or recommendations for specific improvements in pursuance of the
official comprehensive plan.



   (E)   To give aid to the city officials charged with the direction
of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, or parts
thereof, to further the making of the improvements and generally to promote
the realization of the official comprehensive plan.



   (F)   To arrange and conduct any form of publicity relative to its
activities for the general purpose of public understanding.



   (G)   To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions
and other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to
assure harmonious and integrated planning for the area.



   (H)   To exercise other powers germane to those granted under
authority of the Illinois Municipal Code, approved May 29, 1961 and effective
July 1, 1961, and as amended, as may be conferred by the City Council.



(Ord. 64-2, passed 7-14-64)



§ 32.085  STAFF; TECHNICAL ADVISORS.



   (A)   The Plan Commission, with the approval of the City Council,
may employ a paid secretary or staff, or both, whose salaries, wages and
other necessary expenses shall be provided for by the Council from the public
funds.



   (B)   If the Commission deems it advisable to secure technical
advice or services, it may be done upon authority from the Council and
appropriations by the Council therefor.



(Ord. 64-2, passed 7-14-64)



DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC AFFAIRS



§ 32.090  COMMISSIONER TO BE SUPERINTENDENT.



   The Mayor shall be the Commissioner of Public Affairs and the
Superintendent of that department.



(Ord. 0-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.091  ENTITIES UNDER COMMISSIONER’S SUPERVISION.



   The Commissioner of Public Affairs shall have charge of, supervision
and direction over the following subordinate departments, officers, boards,
and municipal functions and services:



   (A)   City Attorney;



   (B)   Planning Commission;



   (C)   Civil defense;



   (D)   Library Board;



   (E)   All officers and employees not assigned to another department
by this chapter; and



   (F)   General supervision over all departments and officers of the
city.



(Ord. 0-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



§ 32.092  DUTIES OF MAYOR.



   The Mayor shall perform all the following duties:



   (A)   Sign all contracts and other official documents to which the
city is a party.



   (B)   Publish all official statements or reports required by law and
all proclamations authorized by the City Council.



   (C)   All the duties of Local Liquor Control Commissioner, as
required by law.



   (D)   Publish all ordinances and resolutions as required by law.



   (E)   Grant all licenses and permits not assigned to another
department.



(Ord. 0-96-21, passed 8-19-96)



BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE  COMMISSIONERS



§ 32.100  ESTABLISHMENT.



   There is hereby established a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
which shall consist of three members whose terms of office shall be three
years and until their respective successors are appointed and have qualified.



(Ord. 0-2001-09, passed 8-20-01)



§ 32.101  APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, shall appoint
the first members of the Board as follows:



      (1)   One member shall be appointed to serve until the end of
the current fiscal year, which ends April 20, 2002;



      (2)   The second member shall be appointed to serve until the
end of the municipal year next ensuing (April 30, 2003); and



      (3)   The third member shall be appointed to serve until the
end of the municipal year second next ensuring (April 30, 2004).



   (B)   Vacancies on the Board shall be filled in the same manner as
the original appointment. 



   (C)   The Board members shall elect a chairperson to serve during
the municipal fiscal year.



   (D)   The Board members shall employ a secretary or designate one of
its own members to act as secretary during the municipal fiscal year.



   (E)   A majority of the Board constitutes a quorum for the conduct
of business.



(Ord. 0-2001-09, passed 8-20-01)



§ 32.102  QUALIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The members of the Board shall be considered officers of the
municipality and shall file with the City Clerk, an oath and a fidelity bond,
which bond shall be in the amount of $1,000.



   (B)   No person holding an office in the city shall be a member of
the Board and the acceptance of any such office by a member of the Board
shall be treated as a resignation. 



   (C)   No person shall be appointed a member of the Board who:



      (1)   Has been convicted of a felony;



      (2)   Is related, either by blood or marriage up to the degree
of first cousin, to any elected official of the city.



   (D)   No more than two members of the Board shall belong to the same
political party.  Party affiliation shall be determined by affidavit of the
person appointed as a member of the Board.



(Ord. 0-2001-09, passed 8-20-01)



§ 32.103  REMOVAL.



   (A)   Members of the Board shall not be subject to removal, except
for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within
30 days in his or her own defense, before a regular meeting of the City
Council.  A majority vote of the members of the City Council shall be
required to remove any such member from office.



   (B)   The Chief of the Fire Department or the Chief of the Police
Department may be removed or discharged by the corporate authority which
shall file a statement of the reasons for such removal or discharge which
shall not become effective unless confirmed by a majority vote of the
corporate authorities.



(Ord. 0-2001-09, passed 8-20-01)



§ 32.104  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.



   (A)   The Board shall appoint all officers and members of the Fire
and Police Departments of the municipality, except the Chief of the Police
Department and except the Chief of the Fire Department, both of whom shall be
appointed by the Mayor with the consent of City Council.



   (B)   The Board shall make rules to carry out its purposes and for
appointments and removals. 



   (C)   The Board, from time to time, may make changes in its rules.



      (1)   All rules and changes therein shall be printed
immediately for distribution.



      (2)   The Board shall give notice of the places where the
printed rules may be obtained and of the date, not less than 10 days
subsequent to the time of publication, when the rules or changes therein
shall go into operation.  The notice shall be published in one or more
newspapers in the municipality.



   (D)   The Board shall make annual reports to the corporate
authorities and shall submit its budget requests annually.



(Ord. 0-2001-09, passed 8-20-01)



AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT



§ 32.115  CREATION.



   There is hereby created an auxiliary police unit to aid and assist the
regular police officers of the city in the performance of their duties.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08)



§ 32.116  APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, is hereby
authorized to appoint auxiliary policemen to the auxiliary police unit. Prior
to appointment, all proposed auxiliary policemen shall make application to,
and authorize criminal background checks by, the Chief of Police of the city.



   (B)   No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary policeman if he
or she has been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral
turpitude.



   (C)   All appointees shall be at least 21 years of age and residents
of the city. The Chief of Police shall submit all approved applicants to the
Mayor and City Council for appropriate action.



   (D)   No elected official of the city shall serve as an auxiliary
policeman during such official’s term of office.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08; Am. Ord. O-2008-07, passed 8-25-08)



§ 32.117  NOT MEMBERS OF POLICE DEPARTMENT AND NOT CONSERVATORS OF THE
PEACE.



   (A)   Auxiliary policemen shall not be members of the regular Police
Department of this city. Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary
policemen shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular
Police Department and shall be selected and chosen by the Chief of Police.



   (B)   Auxiliary policemen shall, at all times during the performance
of their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the Chief of
Police, or a sworn police officer designated by him or her. Auxiliary
officers shall not be conservators of the peace and shall not possess or
exercise conservator of the peace powers.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08)



§ 32.118  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   Auxiliary policemen shall have the following powers and duties when
properly assigned and on duty:



   (A)   To aid or direct traffic in the municipality;



   (B)   To aid in the control of natural or man-made disasters;



   (C)   To aid in case of civil disorder; and



   (D)   To assist members of the regular Police Department in the
performance of their normal and regular police duties when assigned by the
Chief of Police, and subject to such restrictions as may be imposed by the
Chief of Police.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08)



§ 32.119  FIREARMS PROHIBITED.



   Auxiliary policemen shall not carry firearms, except with the
permission of the Chief of Police, and then only when in uniform and in the
performance of their duties.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08)



§ 32.120  TRAINING.



   (A)   Prior to entering upon any of their duties, auxiliary
policemen shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other
police procedures by the Chief of Police or through a course of training
authorized by the Chief of Police. Such course of training shall be not less
than 40 hours in duration.



   (B)   Upon completion of the training, the Chief of Police shall
file a certificate attesting to the auxiliary policeman’s completion of the
course.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08)



§ 32.121  COMPENSATION.



   Auxiliary policemen shall only receive such compensation as may be
authorized from time to time by the City Council, and shall otherwise serve
as volunteers without compensation.



(Ord. O-08-06, passed 7-28-08)



CHAPTER 33:  FINANCE AND TAXATION
