GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 51.01  RESALE OF GAS PROHIBITED.



   No gas shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the
city supply to any premises other than that for which application has been
made and the gas installed.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.02  COMPLAINTS.



   All questions and complaints shall be made to the Gas Department of the
city, which shall be responsible for the proper investigation and record
maintenance.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



§ 51.03  SPECIFICATIONS FOR MAIN AND SERVICE CONNECTIONS.



   The city hereby adopts the requirements of the federal and state
Pipeline Safety Acts as its specifications base.  Gas service connections
made to the mains of the city’s system shall comply with requirements and
regulations set forth within the Acts.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.04  INSTALLATION AND SERVICE OF GAS LINES.



   (A)   The city shall make all connections to gas mains, install all
service lines, and provide the meter and all labor and materials (at the
property owner’s expense) necessary for the installation of gas service
lines. Service line installation shall be completed in a workman like manner.



   (B)   The final tie in for the gas line to the outlet side of the
meter shall be the property owner’s responsibility and must be completed in
accordance with the guidelines set forth in the National Fire Protection
Association’s must recent edition of NFPA 54: National Fuel Gas Code, which
is incorporated by reference and made a part hereof to the same extent as if
fully set forth herein.



   (C)   All customer piping and necessary venting of appliances shall
be in accordance with guidelines set forth in the National Fire Protection
Association’s most recent edition of NFPA 54: National Fuel Gas Code, which
is incorporated herein and by reference made a part hereof.



(Ord. O-2014-07, passed 7-28-14)



ADMINISTRATION



§ 51.10  GAS COMMITTEE.



   In the event the City Council establishes a Gas Committee, all
references in this chapter to the Council shall be construed to mean the
Committee.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



§ 51.11  GAS FUND; ACCOUNTS.



   (A)   Subject to the provisions of Ord. 0-67-11, the City Treasurer
shall receive all of the revenue derived from the city gas system and all
other money and funds incidental to the operation of the system and shall
deposit them in a separate bank account for those funds, separate from all
other funds of the city, and shall administer the Gas Fund in every respect
as in manner and form provided by law and in accordance with the provision
heretofore adopted by the City Council pertaining to the construction,
maintenance and operation of the city gas system or in accordance with any
ordinance hereafter adopted to refund the Gas Public Utility Certificates.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of the City Treasurer to set up and
maintain a proper system of accounts and records separate from all other
accounts and records, showing the amounts received from the gas system and
the application of them and all financial trans- actions connected
therewith.  The accounts shall be audited annually by an independent
certified accountant, as provided by Ord. 0-67-11 and the Illinois Municipal
Accounting Act.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



SERVICE



§ 51.20  APPLICATION FOR SERVICE.



   (A)   Any prospective customer requesting new gas service or an
existing customer requesting additional or changed gas service shall complete
and  file with the City Clerk an application for natural gas service. The
application will be in a form approved by the City Council, copies of which
may be obtained from the office of the City Clerk. The city may require a
security deposit not to exceed $125 in the case of a residential customer
before accepting an application for service.



   (B)   If the prospective customer is a tenant of the premises to be
served, the property owner or the his legal representative or designated
agent, must countersign the application before it will be granted. The
services of the gas system shall be deemed furnished to both the occupant and
the owner of the premises receiving the service and shall be deemed an
obligation of both the occupant and the owner of any such premises.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81; Am. Ord. O-2004-07, passed 4-5-04)  Penalty,
see § 51.99



§ 51.21  SERVICE EXTENSIONS.



   (A)   The city shall not be required to extend service within the
city limits a distance of more than 100 feet per customer, and only then when
sufficient money is available in excess of that required for the proper
operation of the system.  Extension of mains and service outside of the city
limits shall be subject to approval of the City Council, and also shall be
subject to all of the rules and regulations and provisions as provided herein
or as may be amended.  All mains, lines and equipment shall become the
property of the city immediately.



   (B)   Where service is desired when money for extensions is not
available, and/or when the distance is in excess of 100 feet per customer,
the extension can be made if the applicant will deposit with the city the
estimated cost of making the extension, less 100 feet when money is
available, or the entire amount when money is not available. The money so
deposited shall be refunded to the customer at the rate of $.50 per mcf
annually, until the total deposit has been refunded, or until eight annual
payments have been made, whichever occurs first.  The deposit shall be
interest free.  In the event the amount deposited is greater or less than
the actual cost of the extension, the excess or deficiency shall be corrected
before giving service.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



§ 51.22  CITY’S RIGHT TO HALT SERVICE FOR REPAIRS AND LIKE REASONS;
LIABILITY.



   (A)   The city shall have the right to shut off the supply of gas at
any time to make repairs or improve- ments, to enforce rules or for any
operating reason.  Where possible, a reasonable notice of the circum-
stances will be given to the customers, but in an emergency, the gas may be
shut off without notice.  The city shall not be held responsible or liable
because of any shutoff or discontinuance of service or for any direct or
resultant damage to any person, company or customer.



   (B)   In the event of discontinuance, gas service shall not be
renewed until the city authorities have purged the lines.  Authorized
personnel shall relight pilots.  In no case shall the customer turn on his
or her own service.  The purging of lines, relighting pilots and checking
automatic controls will be done by the city.  Where the nature of the
customer’s operations are such that an interruption of service might create
a hazard or large economic loss, the customer shall provide facilities for
standby at his or her discretion.



   (C)   Any customer with critical natural gas requirements must have
dual fuel facilities and on-site storage of the alternate fuel.  Failure to
provide that shall be considered a violation of customer rules and loss or
damage resulting therefrom shall be the responsibility of the customer. 
Those customers shall include, but not be limited to, hospitals, nursing
homes, schools, greenhouses, hatcheries, or any other building or business
which might suffer any type of loss due to interruption of natural gas
service.



   (D)   The city expressly stipulates with all customers and other
persons who may be affected by the discontinuance of service that it neither
will insure nor be responsible or liable in any manner for any loss or
damages direct or indirect by reason of fire, or for any other cause and all
gas service furnished also shall be conditional upon acts of God, inevitable
accidents, failure of supply, fires, strike, riot or any other cause.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.23  SERVICE DISCONTINUANCE FOR NON-PAYMENT OF BILLS.



   (A)   Bills for gas service shall be rendered monthly on or before
the 15th day of each month.  If any bill is not paid in full on or before
the fifth day of the following month, it becomes delinquent and an additional
charge of 10% of the amount of the bill, but not more than $10, shall be
added thereto.  If the fifth day of the month falls on a Saturday, Sunday or
legal holiday, payment of the bill may be made on the first business day
thereafter.



   (B)   If the bill of any gas customer remains delinquent for five or
more days, the City Clerk shall notify the gas customer and the owner of the
property served, if different, in writing by mail, that the gas bill is
delinquent and gas service is to be terminated ten days after the day the
notice is mailed.  The notice specifically shall inform the gas customer of
the following:



      (1)   The customer may contact the City Clerk to request a
hearing on the matter;



      (2)   The request must be made within three working days of
mailing of the delinquency and termination notice;



      (3)   If a request is made, a hearing will be held within five
days of the request;



      (4)   The service will be discontinued within ten days of the
mailing of the notice if no request for a hearing is made.



   (C)   In the event a customer makes a timely request for a hearing
for nonpayment of a delinquent gas bill, the City Clerk at the time the
request is made, shall advise the person of the time, place and date for the
hearing.  The hearing shall be conducted by a hearing officer who will be
the Mayor or a responsible person appointed by the Mayor.  The hearing
officer shall examine evidence submitted by the customer and by the City Gas
Department and, on the basis thereof, shall make findings a to the status of
the customer’s account.



   (D)   If the findings reached at the hearing are adverse to the
customer, they shall be reduced to writing, with a copy thereof to be
forwarded to the customer and to the owner of the property served, by
certified mail, return receipt requested.  The notice also shall contain the
date on which service to the customer will be discontinued.



   (E)   At the time the gas service is to be discontinued, the city
employee disconnecting the gas service to the premises shall deliver to any
occupant of the premises present, or attach to the premises, a written notice
stating the gas service to the premises has been discontinued for the
nonpayment of a delinquent gas bill, the time and date that the service was
discontinued and that the gas service will not be reconnected until the
delinquent bill and any presently due gas bill is paid in full, together with
a reconnection fee of $100 for services within the city and 100 for services
outside the city, and, where applicable, a gas deposit.



   (F)   In the event gas service has been dis- continued due to
nonpayment of bills, it shall not be re-established until the delinquent bill
and any presently due gas bill is paid in full, together with a reconnection
charge of $100 for services within the city and $100 for services outside the
city and, where applicable, a gas deposit.



   (G)   Gas service to a residential customer shall not be
disconnected for nonpayment of bills when the St. Louis National Weather
Service forecast for the following 24 hours forecasts the temperature to be
24°F or lower; nor shall gas service to any customer be discontinued for
nonpayment on a Friday or the day before a holiday.



   (H)   Any delinquency and termination notice provided for in this
section may be combined with a delinquency and termination notice pursuant to
this code pertaining to operation of the combined Waterworks and Sewerage
System of the city.



(Ord. 0-81-3, passed 5-18-81; Am. Ord. 0-86-2, passed 4-7-86; Am. Ord.
0-92-2, passed 4-28-92; Am. Ord. 0-92-15, passed 8-3-92; Am. Ord. 0-96-13,
passed 4-1-96; Am. Ord. O-2016-17, passed 10-24-16)



RATES AND CHARGES



§ 51.30  RATE SCHEDULE.



   (A)   There shall be, and hereby are established, monthly rates and
charges for the sale of natural gas and for the use and service supplied by
the natural gas distribution system of the city, based upon the amount of gas
consumed, as measured by the gas meters, using bases established by the city.



   (B)   The rates and charges to users of the gas utility service of
the city shall be calculated upon a monthly basis and shall be as follows
(any applicable state utility tax shall be added to all billings for each
class of gas service):



      (1)   General service.  First 1,000 cubic feet — $4.99
minimum monthly charge; Over 1,000 cubic feet — $4.35 per 1,000 cubic feet.



      (2)   Industrial Service No. 1.  Industrial rate No. 1
available only by contract and special agreement with the city.



         (a)   All volumes at $4.03 per 1,000 cubic feet.



         (b)   Minimum monthly charge -  $500.



      (3)   Industrial Service No. 2.  Industrial rate No. 2
available only by contract and special agreement with the city.



         (a)   All volumes at $4.13 per 1,000 cubic feet.



         (b)   Minimum monthly charge -  $150.



      (4)   Illinois Department of Corrections.



         (a)   All volumes at $2.90 per 1,000 cubic feet, plus



         (b)   Fixed monthly  charge of $744 for debt retirement.



      (5)   Purchased gas adjustments.  The above stated charges
for natural gas service do not include the city’s delivered cost for the
purchase of natural gas from its supplier, which cost shall be added to the
above stated charges. The City Clerk is hereby empowered and directed to
determine the cost of purchased natural gas on a per thousand cubic feet
basis.  The cost of natural gas charged by the supplier to the city shall be
determined and added to each customer’s bill. Also, there shall be
correspondingly added to each customer’s bill a percentage amount in order
to compensate for distribution system loss. Such percentage amount shall be
the percentage amount shall be the percentage loss reported annually by the
city to the United States Department of Transportation.



   (C)   Monthly gas rate schedule for City Correction Center.



      (1)   In accordance with an Intergovernmental Agreement for
the purchase of water, sewer and gas service between the city and the
Illinois Department of Corrections, the Correctional Center shall pay the
city for all gas supplied by the city using the following rate schedule.



      (2)   Monthly gas rate schedule.  $744 fixed charge for debt
retirement plus delivered cost of purchased gas, and a delivery charge of
$0.51 per 1,000 cubic feet.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81; Am. Ord. O-83-3, passed 8-18-83; Am. Ord.
O-92-2, passed 4-28-92; Am. Ord. O-97-1, passed 1-6-97; Am. Ord. O-97-16,
passed 9-2-97; Am. Ord. O-2002-20, passed 11-5-02; Am. Ord. O-2007-13, passed
12-10-07)



§ 51.31  MISCELLANEOUS CHARGES AND DEPOSITS.



   (A)   If service is disconnected when the final meter reading is
taken, a $100 fee will be charged before service will be re-established, upon
later application for service if the customer resides within the limits of
the city and a $100 fee will be charged before service will be re-established
upon later application for service outside the city limits.



   (B)   Requests for voluntary discontinuance of gas utility service
must be made to the City Clerk by the customer at least two working days
before the date the service is to be turned off.



   (C)   Removal of city service lines from private property will be
made by the city at the request of the customer.  Service charge for removal
of these lines will be on a time-and-materials-cost basis, paid by the
customer.



   (D)   The city shall require a deposit from the prospective
customers before connecting or extending gas service to the customer. 
Deposits shall be in an amount equal to one month’s estimated bill for a
month of peak service to the location.  If, after billing begins at that
location, the estimated deposit proves insufficient to cover one month’s
bill during peak service, the city reserves the right to require an
additional deposit.



   (E)   Deposits shall be non-interest bearing and may be refunded,
upon written application by the customer, after two years of successful
payment of charges.



   (F)   The city may refund meter deposits upon application after the
utility service has been discontinued, provided, the city reserves the right
to inspect the premises before making any refund.



   (G)   All customers receiving gas from the municipal gas system for
which payment for charges for natural gas service has not been received by
the city within 15 days after the date of the bill, shall be charged an
additional 1½% of the bill for each month it remains unpaid after the 15-day
period.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81; Am. Ord. O-86-2, passed 4-7-86; Am. Ord.
O-2016-17, passed 10-24-16)



§ 51.32  CONNECTION CHARGES; PUBLIC UTILITY TAX.



   (A)   All connections to the city gas utility service shall be made
by the city.



      (1)   The city shall charge for connecting ¾- inch taps to
existing mains the sum of $750 for installation of the service line up to 75
feet in length. The charge shall be $1,500 if the connection requires any
boring under any street, alley or roadway.  If the connection requires
trenching or excavation work across any street, alley or roadway rather than
boring, the connection charge shall be $1,750.



      (2)   For installation of service lines in excess of 75 feet,
the city will charge on a time and materials basis for installing the line
and equipment.



   (B)   Additionally, pursuant to the Gas Revenue Act, the city shall
collect a public utility tax of 5% of the total installation charges.



   (C)   In the event a new gas main or extension is required to be
constructed to provide service, customers connecting to the main or extension
will be assessed a proportionate share of the cost required in the
construction of the main or its extension.  The extension policy of the
city, as described in § 51.21, shall apply.



   (D)   Connection charges must be paid in full at the office of the
City Clerk before the city begins work.



      (1)   In the event additional charges become necessary because
of unusual or unexpected circumstances, the charges must be paid in full at
the office of the City Clerk as soon as the work is completed.



      (2)   Under no circumstances will gas service be initiated
until all connection charges are paid in full.



      (3)   Connection charges are non-refundable once work has
begun.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81; Am. Ord. O-2007-03, passed 2-5-07; Am. Ord.
O-2016-17, passed 10-24-16)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.33  MONTHLY METER FEES.



   Customers receiving natural gas service outside the city limits under
the general service rate, as set out in § 51.30, also shall pay a monthly
meter facilities charge of $7 per month.



(Ord. O-86-2, passed 4-7-86)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.34  LIABILITY FOR DELINQUENT CHARGES.



   The owner of any real estate or improvements thereon, or the owner of
the beneficial interest of any trust holding title to land or improvements
served hereunder, shall be responsible for any delinquent  charges for gas
service to the real estate or improvements.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



METERS; OTHER EQUIPMENT



§ 51.40  METERS REQUIRED.



   (A)   No free gas service shall be furnished to any person, firm,
organization or corporation, public or private, and all rates and charges
shall be non- discriminatory, provided the City Council reserves the right to
impose special rates and charges where particular circumstances render the
regular rates inadequate or unjust.  If the city would elect to supply
itself with gas for any purpose, regular rates therefor shall be charged
against the city and payment made from the funds thereof to the Gas Fund.



   (B)   All gas service shall be metered with a meter of adequate size
to measure the amount of gas consumed.  Meters shall be of standard design
and may be of the diaphragm, rotary or turbine type properly used at the
discretion of the city’s Utilities Superintendent.  The measurement
pressure base shall be seven inches water column.



   (C)   All meters shall be placed and installed so as to render them
accessible at all times for the purpose of reading and repairing.  All
meters shall be set outside the buildings where practical. Indoor installa-
tions must be vented with an adequate vent extending to the outside.



   (D)   Under no circumstances shall estimated meter readings be used,
except in the case of meter failure or proven inaccuracy, and then only in
accordance with this chapter.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.41  METER READINGS CONCLUSIVE.



   (A)   All gas customers will be liable for the gas computation as
shown by the meter.  Waste, leakage or other causes not the fault of the
city shall be included under that liability.



   (B)   (1)   The meter reading shall be conclusive, provided when
a meter is found to have a positive average error, i.e., is fast in excess of
2% in tests made at the request of the customer, the city shall refund the
customer an amount equal to the excess charged for the gas incorrectly
metered, for a period of half of the time elapsed since the previous test,
but not to exceed six months.  No part of a minimum charge will be refunded.



      (2)   When a meter is found to have a negative average error,
i.e., is slow in excess of 2% in tests made at the request of the customer,
the city may make a charge to the customer for the gas incorrectly metered
for a period equal to half the time elapsed since the previous test, but not
to exceed six months.



      (3)   If a meter is found not to register for any period, the
city shall estimate the charge for the gas used by averaging the amounts over
similar periods, preceding or subsequent thereto, or over corresponding
periods in previous years.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



§ 51.42  METER TESTS.



   (A)   Any customer may request the city to make a test of the
accuracy of the meter then in use on their premises.  The tests will be made
by the city without charge, provided the meter has not been tested within
seven years preceding such a request.  In case a customer requests an
accuracy test of a meter which has been tested previously within seven years,
the customer shall be required, before the test, to deposit with the city the
sum of $35 to cover the cost of removing, testing and replacing the meter.



   (B)   The test standards described in § 51.41 shall be applicable
in determining accuracy of meters being tested.  Refunds of additional
charges will be based on determinations made according to those standards.



   (C)   In the event a meter is found, by testing, to register
incorrectly at full capacity by more than 2%, the test deposit shall be
refunded.  Past gas bills shall be  adjusted  by the percentage of the
amount  of  the gas bills for a period of not more than six months before
the test.



   (D)   In the event the meter is found to be registering correctly,
the customer shall forfeit the test deposit and the money shall be deposited
in the Gas Operating Funds of the city.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)



§ 51.43  DAMAGE; TAMPERING.



   (A)   Whenever a meter, regulator or other equipment of the city is
found to have been damaged for any cause, the damage shall become the
liability of the customer, who shall pay the city the actual cost of removal,
repair and/or replacement of the damaged equipment.



   (B)   In the event damage has been caused by inaccurate metering,
the gas bills shall be corrected in the manner previously provided for herein.



   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or
customer to break the seal of any meter or in any manner to make alterations,
changes or repairs on the same or to open any mains, laterals, service pipes,
stop cocks, valves or any part thereof or otherwise tamper with or attempt to
do any work on either or any of the same without authority of the city or its
properly authorized agents.  Any person who violates any of the provisions
of this division or who shall willfully or maliciously injure or damage any
property connected with the gas system of the city shall be subject to the
provisions of § 51.99.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.44  INSPECTIONS.



   At all reasonable hours meters, regulators, fittings, fixtures and
appurtenances connected to the system and located on private property shall
be open to inspection by the proper officers or employees of the city.  Any
part found defective or not in compliance with all provisions of this chapter
shall be repaired or corrected immediately.  Service may be discontinued
without notice at any time when conditions of privately or publicly owned
facilities create danger or hazard.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.45  RESPONSIBILITY FOR PIPING IN OR NEAR BUILDINGS.



   (A)   The ownership of and responsibility for city natural gas
piping terminates at the outlet of the customer meter.



   (B)   All house piping shall be of rigid construction.  The pipe
from the outlet of the meter shall be of black iron pipe of not less than
1-inch inside diameter and shall enter the house wall by means of a suitable
metal strap or clamp at a point not more than 18 inches from the outlet
connection of the meter, or if extended along the outside wall, shall be
fastened to the wall at intervals sufficient to make the piping rigid
throughout.  In instances where piping from the meter enters the wall, the
interior end shall be securely fastened so the pipe will not turn when
fittings at the meter are put on.  The final tie-in of the gas line to the
meter shall be made by the city.



   (C)   The National Fire Protection Association, in the latest
revision of NFPA 54, is adopted and incorporated as part of this code of
ordinances as fully as if set out at length herein.



   (D)   All buried natural gas piping facilities and distribution
appurtenances shall conform to the latest revision of the Minimum Federal
Safety Standards Part 192 CFR 49.  Those standards are adopted and
incorporated as part of this code of ordinances as fully as if set out at
length herein.  The minimum standards shall apply equally to private buried
facilities and distribution appurtenances.



   (E)   No ground wire of any type may be or remain attached to any
natural gas piping, whether it is private or city owned.  This prohibition
includes interior piping in buildings.



   (F)   No meter, regulator, or any part of a meter setting may be
painted or otherwise coated by a customer  without written approval of the
city  on  a case-by-case basis.  Special coatings are required to prevent
shorting of insulators.



   (G)   The city shall not approve customer piping, which, as used
herein, means piping beyond the outlet of the meter.  The city may refuse
connection or discontinue service upon discovering any conditions which may
be in violation of this chapter or which may create any type of safety
hazard, including venting.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.46  PROTECTION OF FACILITIES DURING AND FOLLOWING SANITARY SEWER
CONSTRUCTION.



   (A)   Plans and specifications for construction work, specifically
including trenching, must include the general location of all natural gas
service lines and mains which cross the construction or are located within
ten feet of the outer limits of any proposed trenching.



   (B)   A preconstruction conference shall be held not less than two
weeks before the beginning of trenching work and minutes of that conference
shall be maintained in the permanent records of the city gas utility.



   (C)   The preconstruction conference shall be attended by the
Superintendent or other authorized agent of the contractor proposing the
construction or trenching work and by the Superintendent of the city gas
utility, or the Superintendent’s agent.



   (D)   A written request for surface marking must be delivered by the
construction contractor or excavator to the Superintendent of the city gas
utility not less than two full working days before the initiation of
construction or excavation.



   (E)   Gas facilities to be exposed by excavations shall be
specifically identified to the Superintendent of the city gas utility by the
contractor or excavator 24 hours in advance of the time the facilities will
be exposed.



   (F)   The contractor or excavator shall report to the Superintendent
of the city gas utility any incident in which gas facilities are exposed
accidentally, whether damaged or not, not more than two hours following the
accidental exposure.



   (G)   A qualified employee of the city gas utility shall be present
at the site of any excavation occurring within ten feet of any gas service
line or other gas facility.



   (H)   The contractor or excavator shall reimburse the city for the
actual cost of providing a qualified employee by the city gas utility, as
provided in division (G) above.  The costs shall be invoiced by the city gas
utility to the contractor or excavator and shall be due and payable within 30
days of the date of the invoice.



(Ord. O-88-8, passed 8-1-88)  Penalty, see § 51.99



§ 51.99  PENALTY.



   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter
shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $500.



(Ord. O-81-3, passed 5-18-81; Am. Ord. O-2013-08, passed 10-28-13)

GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 52.001  WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM COMBINED.



   The City Council deems it advisable, necessary and in the best interest
of the city that the existing municipally owned waterworks system of the city
and the existing municipally owned sewerage system of the city be combined
and operated and maintained as a combined waterworks and sewerage system, the
combined system to include the entire waterworks and sewerage facilities of
the city, including all future improvements and extensions thereto.



(Ord. O-75-1, passed 5-19-75)



§ 52.002  STATE LAW TO PREVAIL.



   In the event any provision or regulation of this chapter shall be in
conflict with any law of the state, this chapter shall be deemed amended to
conform to the law or regulation.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88)



§ 52.003  USE OF WATER ON CUSTOMER’S PREMISES.



   The city shall have the right to use the water from the customer’s
facilities at any time deemed necessary.  No charge shall be made by the
customer for the use of his or her facilities and no charge shall be made by
the city for the water used by the city.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
0-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.004  CITY NOT LIABLE FOR INTERRUPTIONS OF SERVICE OR SUPPLY.



   (A)   The city shall have the right to shut off the supply of water
and/or sewer service at any time to make repairs, improvements, enforce rules
or for any operating reason.  Where possible, a reasonable notice of the
circumstances will be given to the customers, but in an emergency, water and
sewer service may be shut off without notice.  The city shall not be held
responsible or liable because of any shutoff, discontinuance or service,
failure of any part of the system, for concentration of water or for any
direct or resultant damages to any person, company or customer.



   (B)   In the event of the discontinuance, water and/or sewer
services shall not be renewed until the city authorities have determined it
is in the best interest of the customer to restore the service.  In no case
shall the customer turn on his own service.  The turning on or shutting off
of valves will be done by the city.  Where the nature of the customer’s
operations are such that an interruption of service might create a hazard or
large economic loss, the customer shall provide facilities for standby at his
or her discretion.



   (C)   Any customer with critical water requirements must have an
alternate water source.  Failure to provide it shall be consideration a
violation of customer rules and loss or damages resulting therefrom shall be
the responsibility of the customer.  Those customers shall include, but not
be limited to, manufacturers, hospitals, nursing homes, schools, greenhouses,
hatcheries or any other building or business which might suffer any type of
loss due to interruption of water or sewer service.



   (D)   The city expressly stipulates with all customers and other
persons who may be affected by the discontinuance of service that it will
neither insure nor be responsible or liable in any manner for any loss or
damages, direct or indirect, by reason of fire or any other cause and all
water and sewer service furnished also shall be conditional upon acts of God,
inevitable accidents, failure of supply, fire, strikes, riots or any other
causes.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.005  EASEMENTS.



   The customer shall give easements and rights-of- way as necessary to
the city and allow access for the purposes of construction, repair,
maintenance, meter readings, relocation or expansion of the combined water
and sewerage system.  The necessity shall be determined by the City Council.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.006  EXTENSION POLICY.



   (A)   The city shall not be required to extend service within the
city limits a distance of more than 100 feet per customer and only then when
sufficient funds are available in excess of those required for the proper
operation of the system.  Extension of mains and service outside the city
limits shall be subject to approval of the City Council and also shall be
subject to all of the rules, regulations and provisions as provided herein or
as amended.



   (B)   The Council first shall determine if any extension of water
main is economically feasible, based on the estimated costs of the extension
and the number of existing potential users that will use water along the
extension.  If the extension is economically feasible, the city may install
and pay the cost of the extension at the discretion of the Council.  All
mains, lines and equipment shall immediately become the property of the city.



   (C)   If the Council elects not to pay the costs of extending the
mains, the person or persons desiring the service may install the extension
at their own personal expense, upon the written consent by the Council.  The
city shall not pay for any extension to an undeveloped area, such as a
subdivision being developed, unless there are sufficient existing residents
or businesses to make the extension economically feasible.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.007  RESALE PROHIBITED.



   No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from
the city supply to any premises other than that for which application has
been made.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.008  SPECIFICATIONS FOR MAIN AND SERVICE CONNECTIONS.



   The city does hereby adopt the requirements of the Standard
Specifications for Water Main and Sewer Construction Third Edition, as its
“specification base.” Water and sewerage service connections made to the
system of city shall comply with the specifications.



(Ord. O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.009  USE OF GROUNDWATER AS POTABLE WATER SUPPLY PROHIBITED.



   (A)   The use or attempt to use as a potable water supply
groundwater from within the corporate limits of the city by the installation
or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited.



   (B)   Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section
shall be subject to a fine of up to $100 for each violation.



   (C)   Definitions.   For the purpose of this section, the
following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or
requires a different meaning.



   PERSON. Any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company,
limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company,
trust, estate, political subdivision, or any other legal entity, or their
legal representatives, agents or assigns.



   POTABLE WATER. Any water used for human or domestic consumption,
including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming,
washing dishes or preparing food.



(Ord. O-99-12, passed 6-11-99; Am. Ord. O-2012- 06, passed 8-13-12)



ADMINISTRATION



§ 52.020  WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE COMMITTEE.



   In the event the Council establishes a “Waterworks and Sewerage
Committee” then, in that event, whenever the term “Council” shall
appear in this chapter, the same shall be construed to mean “Waterworks and
Sewerage Committee.”



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.021  WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE FUND.



   Subject to the provisions of Ordinance No. 0-75-5 of the city, the
Treasurer shall receive all of the revenue derived from the combined
Waterworks and Sewerage System and all other monies and funds incidental to
the operation of the system and shall deposit them in a separate bank account
for the funds, separately from all other funds of the city and shall
administer the Waterworks and Sewerage Fund in every respect as in manner and
form provided by law and in accordance with the provision heretofore adopted
by the Council pertaining to the construction, maintenance, and operation of
the combined waterworks and sewerage system, or in accordance with any
ordinance adopted to refund the waterworks sewerage revenue bonds.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.022  ACCOUNTS AND RECORDS.



   It shall be the duty of the City Treasurer to set up and maintain a
proper system of accounts and records separate from all other accounts and
records, showing the amounts received from the Waterworks and Sewerage System
and the application of the amounts and all financial transactions in
connection therewith.  The accounts shall annually be audited by an
independent certified accountant as provided by ordinance and as provided by
the Illinois Municipal Accounting Act.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-97-7, passed 6-16-97)



§ 52.023  WATER LEAK INSURANCE COVERAGE.



   (A)   The Mayor and City Clerk are authorized to procure and place
in force water leak insurance coverage through Sunbelt Insurance Group to
provide coverage for lost city revenue resulting from adjustments to customer
water and sewer bills for customer water leaks.



   (B)   Effective with bills for city water and sewer services issued
in October 2017, the city shall charge each water and sewer customer of city
the sum of $ 1.40 per month to apply toward the premium cost of the water
leak insurance coverage. Such monthly charge shall be in addition to the
monthly charges for usage.



   (C)   Any water or sewer customer of the city who wishes to
terminate or prevent the monthly charge for the water leak insurance premium
may decline coverage and waive the right to request bill adjustments by
signing and delivering to the City Clerk a written election to decline such
coverage. The City Clerk shall provide an election form to any customer upon
request. No charge for water leak insurance shall be added to any subsequent
monthly bill for any water or sewer customer who provides the written
election form to the City Clerk. City water and sewer customers who decline
insurance coverage and who waive the right to request an adjustment to water
and sewer bills shall remain responsible for payment of all water and sewer
charges in full as shown by the metered usage as provided in § 52.051 of the
City Code. Such customers shall not be entitled to any adjustment of excess
charges resulting from leaks in customer’s service lines.



   (D)   For any city water and sewer customer who pays the monthly
charge for the premium cost of water leak insurance, the customer may one
time each twelve month period request an adjustment to the customer’s water
and sewer bill and a reduction in “excess charges” resulting from leaks
in customer’s water lines. The excess charges shall be calculated to equal
the amount by which a monthly bill for water and sewer services exceeds the
preceding 12 month average bill for such customer. The city as an exception
to § 52.051 of the City Code will forgive one half the amount of such excess
charges upon proof that customer has repaired the leak. The customer shall be
responsible for payment of the remaining one half share of the excess
charges, plus the charges equal to customer’s preceding 12 month average
bill. Customer shall be entitled to an adjustment for charges arising from
water leaks one time during each 12 month period. Any customer who is allowed
an adjustment will cooperate with city to support the claim for benefits
under the city’s water leak insurance coverage.



(Ord. O-2017-21, passed 7-24-17)



RATES AND CHARGES



§ 52.030  SCHEDULE OF WATER AND SEWERAGE RATES.



   (A)   In general.  There shall be, and there are hereby
established, monthly rates and charges for the sale of water and for the use
and services supplied by the combined Waterworks and Sewerage system of the
city.  The minimum monthly bill will by payable irrespective of use.  Any
applicable state utility tax shall be added to all billings.  Special rates
for water or water and sewer service may be made, from time to time, by
separate contract with special customers, subject to the rates, terms and
conditions determined by the City Council to be in the best interest of the
Combined Waterworks and Sewerage System of the city.



   (B)   Water rates.



      (1)   Inside city limits.  The rates and charges to users of
the combined water-works and sewerage system of the city who are located
within the limits of the city shall be calculated upon a monthly basis and
shall be as follows:

Each additional 1,000 gallons
 
$5.50

$13.00


Each additional 1,000 gallons
 
$6.00


Illinois Department of Corrections


Each 1,000 gallons
 
$6.00




 



      (2)   Outside city limits.  The rates and charges to users of
the combined water-works and sewerage system located outside the limits of
the city for water shall be calculated upon a monthly basis and shall be as
follows:



 

 
Rate

First 2,000 gallons
 
$18.50


Each additional 1,000 gallons
 
$8.00

   (C)   Sewer rates.



      (1)   Rates and charges for the use and services of the
city’s sewerage system are based on water consumption as indicated by the

follows.

$8.00



 



      (2)   The rates and charges for Illinois Department of
Corrections for use and service of the city’s sewerage system shall be
calculated upon a monthly basis and shall be as follows.



         (a)   $16,291 fixed rate for debt retirement.



         (b)   Plus $6.00 per 1,000 gallons of water used for
operation, maintenance and replacement.



   (D)   No sewer rate shall be charged for water flowing through a
water meter which is used solely and exclusively for a watering or sprinkler
system for grass or other vegetation.



(Ord. O-82-1, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. O-88-5, passed 4-18-88; Am. Ord.
O-92-3, passed 4-28-92; Am. Ord. O-93-3, passed 6-7-93; Am. Ord. O-97-7,
passed 6-16-97; Am. Ord. O-98-2, passed 1-20-98; Am. Ord. O-2007-14; Am. Ord.
O-2016-17, passed 10-24-16)
