GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 110.01  DEFINITIONS.



   (A)   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different
meaning.



   CITY.  The city of Pinckneyville, Illinois.



   LICENSE.  A license issued under this chapter or by the Illinois
Liquor Control Commission, as the context may require.



   LICENSED PREMISES. The entire tract of land described in any license
and all buildings thereon.



   LICENSEE.  Any person or entity to whom a license is issued.



   LIQUOR CONTROL ACT or THE ACT.  “An Act Relating to Alcoholic
Liquors,” ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, approved January 21, 1934, as now in force
and hereafter amended.



   (B)   When words or phrases are used in this chapter which are
defined in ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, Art. I, such words or phrases shall have the
meaning and are used in this chapter in the sense given them in ILCS Ch. 235,
Act 5, Art. I.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96)



§ 110.02  SCOPE OF CHAPTER.



   No person shall manufacture, bottle, blend, sell, barter, transport,
deliver, furnish or possess any alcoholic liquor within the corporate limits
of the city, except as specifically provided in this chapter and the Liquor
Control Act, and except as further provided in ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, Art. II.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.03  PEDDLING PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the city.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.04  CONDITION OF LICENSED PREMISES.



   All licensed premises shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition
and shall be kept in full compliance with ordinances regulating the condition
of premises used for the storage or sale of foods for human consumption.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.05  CONDITION OF EMPLOYEES.



   It shall be unlawful to employ in any licensed premises any person who
is afflicted with or a carrier of any infectious or communicable disease.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.06  INSURANCE.



   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to maintain dram shop
insurance coverage for the licensed premises. All licensees shall provide the
city with evidence of dram shop insurance in the form of a certificate of
insurance issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-2004-19, passed 11-15-04) Penalty,
see § 110.99



§ 110.07  UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW; LIGHTING.



   In Class A licensed premises, no screen, blind, curtain, partition, or
other thing shall be permitted in or about the interior of such premises
which shall prevent a clear and full view of the entire premises from the
entrance of such premises. All rooms in Class A licenses premises shall be
continuously lighted during business hours by natural light or artificial
white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be
clearly visible. In case the view into any such licensed premises required by
the foregoing provision shall be willfully obscured by the licensee or by him
willfully suffered to be obscured, or in any manner obstructed, then his
license shall be subject to revocation. In order to enforce the provisions of
this section, the Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall have the right to
require the filing with him of the plans, drawings, and photographs showing
the appearance of the view as herein required.



(Ord. 0-96-22, passed 9-16-96)  Penalty, see § 110.99



ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT



§ 110.20  MAYOR TO SERVE AS LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER; POWERS AND
DUTIES.



   (A)   The Mayor of the city hereby is appointed Local Liquor Control
Commissioner.



   (B)   The Commissioner shall have and exercise all the rights,
powers, functions and duties granted, conferred, imposed or provided by the
Liquor Control Act.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)



§ 110.21  SALARY OF COMMISSIONER, DEPUTIES AND ASSISTANTS.



   (A)   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall be paid the sum of
$1,200 annually, payable quarterly, for compensation as Commissioner.



   (B)   The compensation of deputies, assistants and employees
appointed by the Commissioner, not to exceed four in number, shall be $15 per
day for each day they actually shall be engaged in the performance of their
duties.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)



LICENSES



§ 110.30  STATE PROVISIONS ADOPTED.



   (A)   The provisions of ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, Art. VI, and ILCS Ch.
235, Act 5, §§ 5-5, 7-7, 7-9, 7-10 and 7-11 and ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, §§
10-2 through 10-10, of the Liquor Control Act, except the penalty provisions,
are adopted and incorporated as part of this code of ordinances as fully as
if set out at length herein.



   (B)   The sections shall apply to all licenses issued under this
chapter, and all applications therefor.



   (C)   Any violation of the above-numbered sections of the Act shall
be deemed a violation of this chapter, and shall be punishable by a fine as
provided in § 110.99, which punishment shall be in lieu of any penalty
prescribed by any section of the Act.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)



§ 110.31  LICENSE REQUIRED; ELIGIBILITY.



   (A)   No person shall sell, barter, transport, deliver or furnish at
retail any alcoholic liquor (subject to the provisions, conditions and
exceptions set forth in § 110.02) within the corporate limits of the city
without first having secured a license therefor, as provided in this
subchapter.



   (B)   Eligibility for a license shall be determined by the
provisions of the Liquor Control Act, ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 6-2.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.32  APPLICATION.



   Any application for a license shall be substantially in the form
provided by the Liquor Control Act, ILCS Ch. 235, Act 5, § 7-1.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)



§ 110.33  CLASSES OF LICENSES.



   Licenses issued hereunder shall be of the following classes:



   (A)   Class A.  This license shall entitle the licensee to sell or
offer for sale at retail alcoholic liquor for use or consumption on the
premises described in the license, or elsewhere, but not for resale in any
form.



   (B)   Class B.  This license shall entitle the licensee to sell or
offer for sale at retail alcoholic liquor in its original package and not
otherwise, but not for resale in any form, provided, no alcoholic liquor
shall be used or consumed on the premises described in the license.



   (C)   Class C. This license shall entitle the licensee to sell or
offer for sale at retail malt liquor known as beer and wine, for use or
consumption on the premises described in the license, but not for resale in
any form. Any beer or wine sold or offered for consumption under this class
of license shall not be dispensed in a glass container of any type. Class C
licenses are not subject to the provisions of § 110.38.



   (D)   Class D.  Such license shall entitle the licensee as a
caterer retailer to serve alcoholic liquors as an incidental part of a food
service that serves prepared meals which excludes the serving of snacks as a
primary meal, either on or off site, whether licensed or unlicensed.



   (E)   Class E.  This license shall entitle the licensee to:



      (1)   Serve wine for use and consumption on the premises
described in the license, for sampling purposes only, provided that the
licensee shall serve no more than five 2-ounce samples to any person; and



      (2)   Offer for sale wine in its original package for sale and
not otherwise, provided that no wine offered for sale shall be used or
consumed on the premises described in the license, excepting the samples of
wine served in accordance with division (E)(1) of this section.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-2007-01, passed 1-2-07; Am. Ord.
O-2007-09, passed 8-13-07)  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.34  NUMBER OF LICENSES PER CLASS.



   (A)   The number of Class A licenses shall be limited to ten and at
any time when ten Class A licenses have been issued and are in force, no
other Class A licenses shall be issued.



   (B)   The number of Class B licenses shall be limited to ten.  Any
time ten Class B licenses have been issued and are in force, no other Class B
licenses shall be issued.



   (C)   The number of Class C licenses shall be limited to five.  Any
time five Class C licenses have been issued and are in force, no other Class
C licenses shall be issued.



   (D)   The number of Class D licenses shall be limited to five.  Any
time five Class D licenses have been issued and are in force, no other Class
D licenses shall be issued.



   (E)   The number of Class E licenses shall be limited to five, and
at any time when five Class E licenses have been issued and are in force, no
other Class E licenses shall be issued.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-97-22, passed 11-17-97; Am. Ord.
O-2007-09, passed 8-13-07; Am. Ord. O-2017-32, passed 11-13-17)  Penalty,
see § 110.99



§ 110.35  LICENSE FEE.



   (A)   The annual license fee for such licenses shall be $500 for
Class A licenses, $350 for Class B licenses, $50 per day or fraction thereof
for Class C licenses, and $100 for Class D licenses, all payable in advance.
The license fee for Class E licenses shall be $50 per day, payable in advance.



   (B)   No application shall be considered, acted upon or granted,
until and unless such application for such license has been filed and a
receipt showing payment of the license fee is attached to such application.



   (C)   All license fees shall be paid to the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner who shall forthwith remit the sum to the City Treasurer. In the
event the license applied for is denied, the fee shall be refunded to the
applicant.



   (D)   In no case shall any license fee or part thereof be refunded
after a license is issued; provided, however, that if any licensee having
held a license for a continuous period of at least five years, surrenders its
license during a license year, it shall receive a refund equal to the
difference between the annual license fee of $500 and the sum of $100 for
each month from the date of issuance of the license to the date of its
surrender.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-2007-09, passed 8-13-07)  Penalty,
see § 110.99



§ 110.36  CONTENTS.



   Licenses shall state thereon the class to which they belong, the name
or names of the licensee, the address and legal description of the premises
for which they are granted and the dates of their issuance and expiration.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.37  TERM.



   All licenses shall be valid for not to exceed one year after issuance,
unless sooner revoked or suspended, as in this chapter or the Liquor Control
Act provided, and shall expire on April 30 next following their issuance. 
Provided, however, that Class E licenses shall only be valid on the date for
which they are issued.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-2007-09, passed 8-13-07)  Penalty,
see § 110.99



§ 110.38  STREETS ON WHICH LICENSEES MAY BE LOCATED.



   (A)   Unless the written consent of the owners of at least ¾ of the
frontage feet along the street or streets adjacent to the premises for a
distance of 200 feet in all directions from the premises is filed with an
application, a license shall be issued only to an applicant at premises
located on one of the following described portions of streets in the city:



      (1)   South Walnut Street between West Water Street and West
Randolph Street.



      (2)   The east side of North Gordon Street between the north
line of Clinton Street and the south line of West North Street, extended
eastwardly to intersect with the east line of North Gordon Street.



      (3)   The north side of West Parker between South Mill Street
and South Douglas Street.



      (4)   West Water Street between Grant Street and the west
corporate boundary of the city.



      (5)   The east side of South Main Street between Chester
Street and Parker Street.



      (6)   The west side of South Main Street between Roe Street
and Parker Street.



      (7)   The east side of South Main Street between Water Street
and Randolph Street.



      (8)   Main Street on the west side of the public square
between Water Street and Jackson Street.



      (9)   North side of Parker Street for a distance of 150 feet
east of its intersection with Main Street.



      (10)   The south side of State Route 154 between Sap Road and
Holts Prairie Road.



      (11)   South Main Street from Water Street to Brown Street.



   (B)   As used in this section, the following definitions shall apply:



      OWNERS.  Includes every person having any interest in any land
the frontage feet of which is included in the prescribed distance of 200 feet
in all directions from the premises, including tenants and contract
purchasers.



      PREMISES.  The place of business where the applicant proposes to
sell alcoholic liquor and includes all the land embraced in the legal
description of the deed, lease or other writing under which the applicant
claims the right to occupy the land.



      STREET OR STREETS ADJACENT TO SUCH PREMISES.  Includes the
street or streets on which the premises abut in any direction, and all
streets which intersect such street or streets.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-97-22, passed 11-17-97; Am. Ord.
O-99-2, passed 2-1-99; Am. Ord. O-2003-05, passed 9-2-03; Am. Ord. O-2012-02,
passed 3-12-12) Penalty, see § 110.99



TIMES OF OPERATION



§ 110.50  DAYS AND HOURS PERMITTED FOR CONDUCT OF BUSINESS.



   (A)   Unless otherwise authorized by the City Council, it shall be
unlawful for any licensee described in the Liquor Control Act, ILCS Ch. 235,
Art. 10, § 3 to sell, dispense, barter, deliver, furnish or give away any
alcoholic liquor in the city, except as follows:



      (1)   From 6:00 a.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday,
Friday and Saturday until 1:00 a.m. on the next day; and



      (2)   From 6:00 a.m. on Sunday until 1:00 a.m. on the next day
for a Class B licensee and from 12:00 p.m. on Sunday until 1:00 a.m. for a
Class A, Class C and Class D licensee.



   (B)   During the days and hours specified in division (A) above, it
shall be unlawful for any licensed premises to remain open for business, or
to admit any person thereon, or for any alcoholic liquor to be consumed
thereon, except:



      (1)   A shop, bowling alley, restaurant or hotel operated upon
a licensed premises may remain open during the days and hours for the purpose
of conducting the usual business thereof, and



      (2)   Any local unit of a recognized national fraternal or
benevolent order or organization which holds a license may remain open during
the days and hours for the purpose of conducting fraternal or private social
meetings usually held on the premises, provided, in either case, the bar or
other place where alcoholic liquor is sold, dispensed or delivered shall be
and remain closed.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96; Am. Ord. O-2004-02, passed 2-17-04; Am. Ord.
O-2004-18, passed 11-5-04)  Penalty, see § 110.99



MINORS



§ 110.60  POSSESSION OR CONSUMPTION.



   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 21 to possess or
consume alcoholic liquor.



(Ord. O-96-34, passed 12-16-96)  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.61  SALE OR DELIVERY TO PROHIBITED.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, furnish, deliver,
procure or make available any alcoholic liquor to or for any person under the
age of 21 years.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)  Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.62  FALSE REPRESENTATION OF AGE.



   It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent that he or she
is of age for the purpose of buying accepting or receiving alcoholic liquor.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.63  EMPLOYMENT.



   (A)   This chapter shall not prohibit any minor from working on the
premises of an establishment holding any class of license herein described,
but it shall be unlawful for any minor, employee or not, to pour or mix
alcoholic liquor at such an establishment.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any minor to be present at an
establishment holding a Class A license, unless the minor is present in an
employment capacity or is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian 21 years
of age or older.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96) Penalty, see § 110.99



§ 110.99  PENALTY.



   Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not
less than $100 nor more than $1,000 for each offense.  A separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs
or continues. However, such fine shall not exceed $10,000.



(Ord. O-96-22, passed 9-16-96)



CHAPTER 111:  MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS



Section



General Provisions



   111.01   Nuisance declared



   111.02   Definitions



Unlawful Practices



   111.10   Prohibited acts enumerated



 



   111.99   Penalty



GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 111.01  NUISANCE DECLARED.



   The City Council hereby determines the existence, maintenance and
operation of massage parlors affect the public health, safety and morals and
constitute a nuisance.



(Ord. 0-76-6, passed 4-19-76)



§ 111.02  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   CALL SERVICES.  Providing or furnishing the services of a massage
technician for the purpose of giving or administering a massage for sexual
stimulation at a location other than a massage parlor.



   MASSAGE.



      (1)   Any method of pressure on, friction against, stroking,
kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating or stimulating of the
external soft parts of the body with the hands or with the aid of any
mechanical or electrical apparatus, device or appliance, with or without the
use of materials such as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptic oils, powder,
creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparation.



      (2)   The term excludes a massage admini- stered by a person
registered under the Illinois Physical Therapy Registration Act and does not
include the particular massages defined in the practice of barbering set
forth in ILCS Ch. 225, Act 410, § 2-1 or the practice of cosmetology, as
defined in ILCS Ch. 225, Act 410, § 3-1, when performed by registered
barbers or registered cosmetologists or their lawfully authorized assistants.



   MASSAGE PARLOR.  Any place, premises, room or other area where any
person, for money or other consideration, may receive a massage or related
services for the purposes of sexual stimulation.



   MASSAGE TECHNICIAN.  Any male or female person who, in connection with
the activities of a massage parlor, administers a massage to another person
or performs or provides any related services.



   RELATED SERVICES.  Furnishing, displaying or exhibiting at any massage
parlor any photographs, books, pictures, drawings, motion pictures with or
without sound, depicting any nude person or sexual activity or playing any
record, tape or other recording of any sexual activity or providing the
services of a massage technician in the nude or clothed only about the sexual
area or permitting or furnishing facilities or accommodations for the
commission of any sexual act by one person or between or among any two or
more persons.



   SEXUAL AREA.  The genitals, pubic area, buttocks, anus or perineum of
any person or the vulva or breasts of a female.



   SEXUAL STIMULATION.  Any act, conduct or procedure in or at a massage
parlor designed or intended to arouse, appeal to or gratify the lust, passion
or sexual desire of a person.  SEXUAL STIMULATION includes, but is not
limited to, giving or administering a massage in or to the sexual area,
fondling or touching the sexual area of a massage technician, observing,
listening to, performing or participating in the related services defined in
this chapter.



(Ord. 0-76-6, passed 4-19-76)



UNLAWFUL PRACTICES



§ 111.10  PROHIBITED ACTS ENUMERATED.



   It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person:



   (A)   To open, operate or maintain a massage parlor.



   (B)   To rent, lease, furnish or otherwise make available any place,
premises, room or other area for use as a massage parlor.



   (C)   To give or administer a massage, as defined in this chapter.



   (D)   To furnish or provide any related services, as defined in this
chapter.



   (E)   To encourage, aid, permit, assist or engage in the sexual
stimulation of any person in or at a massage parlor.



   (F)   To provide or furnish call services, as defined in this
chapter.



(Ord. 0-76-6, passed 4-19-76)  Penalty, see § 111.99



§ 111.99  PENALTY.



   Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this
chapter, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $100 nor more than
$200 for the first conviction.  Any person convicted of a second or
subsequent violation shall be fined not less than $200 nor more than $500. 
Each day a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate offense.



(Ord. 0-76-6, passed 4-19-76; Am. Ord. O-2013-08, passed 10-28-13)



CHAPTER 112:  TRANSIENT MERCHANTS; ITINERANT VENDORS; SOLICITORS



Section



Transient Merchants; Itinerant Vendors



   112.01   Definitions



   112.02   Exemptions



   112.03   Certificate of bond and license required



   112.04   Seizure of property



   112.05   Proof of status as transient or itinerant



Solicitors



   112.15   Definitions



   112.16   City policy



   112.17   Notice



   112.18   Certificate of registration



   112.19   Nuisance declared



 



   112.99   Penalty



TRANSIENT MERCHANTS; ITINERANT VENDORS



§ 112.01  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   ITINERANT VENDOR.  Any person who transports tangible personal
property for retail sale within the city who does not maintain an established
office, distribution house, sales house, warehouse, service center or
residence from which the business is conducted.



   TRANSIENT MERCHANT.  Any person who is engaged temporarily in the
retail sale of goods, wares or merchandise in the city and who, for the
purpose of conducting the business, occupies any building, room, vehicle,
structure of any kind or vacant lot.



(Ord. 0-88-2, passed 3-21-88)



§ 112.02  EXEMPTIONS.



   This subchapter does not apply to:



   (A)   Any person selling goods, wares or mer- chandise which are
raised, produced or manufactured by him or her.



   (B)   Any person selling vegetables, fruit or perishable farm
products at a market established by the city.



   (C)   Any person operating a stand or booth on or adjacent to
property owned by him or upon which he or she resides.



   (D)   Any person operating a stand or booth at a county fair.



   (E)   Any person holding a valid license issued by the city to
engage in retail sales.



   (F)   Any person who delivers tangible personal property within the
city who is fulfilling an order for the property which was solicited or
placed by mail or other means.



(Ord. 0-88-2, passed 3-21-88)



§ 112.03  CERTIFICATE OF BOND AND LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   It is a violation of this subchapter for any person, either as
principal or agent, to conduct business as a transient merchant or vendor in
this city without first complying with the requirements of the Illinois
Retailers Occupation Tax Act, ILCS Ch. 35, Act 120, § 2a, by obtaining a
certificate of registration and by posting bond or other approved security
and without having obtained a license under this subchapter.



   (B)   Any person who wishes to obtain a license as a transient
merchant or itinerant vendor shall file a written license application with
the city’s Police Department.



      (1)   The license application shall include the applicant’s
name, permanent business address (which must include a street address),
residence address of the principal (and, if the applicant is a corporation,
the residence addresses of its officers), the location at which the applicant
intends to do business, the nature of the business the applicant intends to
conduct, a copy of the applicant’s certificate of registration under the
Retailers Occupation Tax Act, a complete inventory of the goods the applicant
intends to offer for sale and a list of all licenses to conduct business as a
transient merchant or an itinerant vendor obtained by the applicant in this
state in the 12 months preceding the date of filing of the application.



      (2)   The applicant shall file with the city’s Police
Department a surety bond or shall make a cash deposit.  The amount of the
bond or deposit shall be equal to 50% of the wholesale value of the merchan-
dise the applicant intends to offer for sale.  The amount of the bond or
deposit shall not be less than $1,000 or more than $10,000.



      (3)   The Police Department shall transfer the deposit or bond
to the Illinois Attorney General within 14 days after the applicant ceases to
do business in its jurisdiction, and the Attorney General shall hold the
deposit or bond for two years for the benefit of any person who suffers loss
or damage as a result of the purchase of merchandise from the person licensed
under this subchapter or as a result of the negligent or intentionally
tortious act of the person licensed under this subchapter.  The Attorney
General shall pay any portion of the bond or deposit to any person in
accordance with the order of a court without making an independent finding as
to the amount of the bond or deposit that is payable to that person.  Any
balance of the deposit held by the Attorney General two years after the
expiration of a license of a person under this subchapter shall be refunded
to the person.



      (4)   A license issued under this subchapter shall expire on
December 31 of the year it is issued.  The Police Department shall collect a
license application fee of $100 from any person wishing to conduct business
as either a transient merchant or itinerant vendor under this subchapter.



(Ord. 0-88-2, passed 3-21-88)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.04  SEIZURE OF PROPERTY.



   (A)   If any person makes retail sales as a transient merchant or
itinerant vendor without having obtained a license under this subchapter, the
city’s Police Department may hold the inventory, truck or other personal
property of the person until he or she obtains a license to conduct business
as a transient merchant or itinerant vendor.



   (B)   If the property has been held by the Police Department for
more than 60 days and the person whose property is being held has not
obtained a license under this subchapter, the city may petition the circuit
court for an order for the sale of the property being held.



      (1)   If the court finds the person whose property is held has
not obtained a license, the court may order the city to sell the property.



      (2)   Proceeds of the sale of the property, less reimbursement
to the Police Department of the reasonable expenses of storage and sale of
the property, shall be deposited in the city treasury.



(Ord. 0-88-2, passed 3-21-88)



§ 112.05  PROOF OF STATUS AS TRANSIENT OR ITINERANT.



   It shall be prima facie evidence that a person is a transient merchant
or itinerant vendor under this subchapter if the person does not transact
business from a fixed location or if the person does not own or lease, for a
term of at least six months, the property from which business is conducted.



(Ord. 0-88-2, passed 3-21-88)



SOLICITORS



§ 112.15  DEFINITIONS.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   REGISTERED SOLICITOR.  Any person who has obtained a valid Certificate
of Registration and has it in his or her possession when engaged in
soliciting.



   RESIDENCE.  Every separate living unit occupied for residential
purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or
structure.



   SOLICITING.  Any one or more of the following activities:



      (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods,
wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or
description, for any consideration.



      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application
or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character.



      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines,
periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication.



      (4)   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money,
clothing or any other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any
charitable or non-profit association, organization, corporation or project.



(Ord. 79-12, passed  - -79)



§ 112.16  CITY POLICY.



   It hereby is declared the policy of the City Council that occupants of
residences in the city shall determine whether solicitors shall or shall not
be invited to their respective residences.  If no deter- mination is made,
as provided in § 112.17(A), regis- tration is not required.



(Ord. 79-12, passed  - -79)



§ 112.17  NOTICE.



   (A)   Every person desiring to secure the protec- tion intended to
be provided by this subchapter shall give notice of their determination
whether to invite or refuse invitation to solicitors by exhibiting upon or
near the main entrance door to the residence a weatherproof card,
approximately 3 x 4 inches in size.



      (1)   The card shall contain the applicable words, as
follows: 



   “ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED BY THE



   CITY OF PINCKNEYVILLE POLICE



   DEPARTMENT INVITED”



   or



   “NO SOLICITORS INVITED.” 



(Letters on the card shall be at least -inch in height.)



      (2)   For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be
provided by the Police Chief to persons requesting them at the cost thereof.



      (3)   The card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice
to any solicitors of the determination by the occupant of the residences of
the information contained thereon.



   (B)   It shall be the duty of every solicitor, upon going onto any
premises in the city upon which a residence is located, to examine the notice
provided for in division (A) above, if any is attached, and be governed by
the statement contained on it.



      (1)   If the notice states “ONLY SOLICITORS REGISTERED BY
THE CITY OF PINCKNEYVILLE POLICE DEPARTMENT INVITED,” the solicitor not
possessing a valid Certificate of Registration shall depart immediately and
peacefully from the premises.



      (2)   If the notice states “NO SOLICITORS INVITED,” the
solicitor, whether registered or not, shall department immediately and
peacefully from the premises.



   (C)   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence,
whether invited or not, shall department immediately and peacefully from the
premises when requested to do so by the occupant.



(Ord. 79-12, passed  - -79)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.18  CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION.



   (A)   Every person desiring to engage in soliciting from persons in
residences within the city hereby is required to make written application for
a Certificate of Registration.



   (B)   Application for a Certificate of Registration shall be made
upon a form provided by the Police Chief and filed with the Chief.  The
applicant shall state truthfully and in full under oath the information
requested on the application, to wit:



      (1)   The name and address of the applicant’s present place
of business and length of residence at the address; the business address, if
other than the residence address and the applicant’s social security number.



      (2)   The address of the applicant’s place of residence
during the past three years, if other than the present address.



      (3)   A physical description of the applicant.



      (4)   The name and address of the person, firm, corporation or
association by which the applicant is employed or represents and the length
of time of that employment.



      (5)   The name and address of the applicant’s employer
during the past three years, if other than the present employer.



      (6)   A description sufficient for identifica- tion of the
subject matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage.



      (7)   The period of time for which the Certificate is applied.



      (8)   The date, or approximate date, of the applicant’s
latest previous application for a Certificate under this subchapter, if any.



      (9)   Whether a Certificate issued to the applicant under this
subchapter ever has been revoked.



      (10)   Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter or a city ordinance
regarding soliciting.



      (11)   Whether the applicant ever has been convicted of a
felony under the laws of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the
United States.



      (12)   Additional information as the Police Chief may deem
necessary to process the application.



   (C)   The Police Chief shall require every applicant to submit to
finger printing by the city’s Police Department in connection with the
application for a Certificate.



   (D)   The Chief shall cause to be kept in his or her office an
accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with
all other information and data pertaining thereto and all Certificates of
Registration issued under the provisions of this subchapter.  Applications
for Certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed and every
Certificate issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with the
duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued.



   (E)   No Certificate shall be issued to any person who has been
convicted of a felony under the laws of this state or any other state or
federal law of the United States within five years of the date of the
application, nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any
of the provisions of this subchapter, nor to any person whose Certificate
issued hereunder has been revoked previously, as herein provided.



(Ord. 79-12, passed  - -79)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.19  NUISANCE DECLARED.



   (A)   It hereby is declared unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any
door or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the
attention of the occupant of the residence for the purpose of securing an
audience, and engage in soliciting in defiance of the notice exhibited at the
residence in accordance with the provisions of § 112.17(A).



   (B)   It hereby is declared unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance
for any person, whether registered under this subchapter or not, to go upon
any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence
located thereon, or rap or knock upon the door, or create any sound in any
other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of the
residence for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant and
engage in soliciting, before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. of any week day,
any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.



(Ord. 79-12, passed  - -79)  Penalty, see § 112.99



§ 112.99  PENALTY.



   (A)   Any person who is convicted of violating any provision of §§
112.01 through 112.05 is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor.  Any person who is
convicted of committing a second or subsequent violation of §§ 112.01
through 112.05 is guilty of a Class 4 felony. 



(Ord. 0-88-2, passed 3-21-88)



   (B)   Any person violating any of the provisions of §§ 112.15
through 112.19, upon conviction, shall be fined not less than $100 nor more
than $500 for each offense.



(Ord. 79-12, passed  - -79; Am. Ord. O-2013-08, passed 10-28-13)

REGULATION OF POOL ROOMS



§ 114.01  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   Every person keeping for use any billiard table, pool table or any
other tables or implements for a similar purpose and open to the public,
shall pay a license fee of $10 per year for the first billiard table, or
other table, he or she may keep, and $7.50 per year for each additional table
located in the same building.



(Ord. O-2000-14, passed 7-3-00)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.02  HOURS OF OPERATION.



   No poolroom or pool hall or other place where pool, billiard or similar
tables are kept or used shall be open to the public or open for business of
any kind as follows:



   (A)   On Sunday between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 1:00 p.m.,
nor after 11:00 p.m. on Sunday.



   (B)   On all other days between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m.



(Ord. O-2000-14, passed 7-3-00)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.03  MINORS PROHIBITED.



   Minors under the age of 16 years shall under no circumstances frequent,
loiter, go or remain in any pool hall within the city at any time, unless it
be upon some lawful errand and sent by the direction and with the consent and
knowledge of the parent, guardian or other person having the legal custody
and control of said minor; and that proprietors of pool halls are not allowed
to permit minors under the age of 16 to frequent, loiter or remain within
pool halls.



(Ord. O-2000-14, passed 7-3-00)  Penalty, see § 114.99



HALLOWEEN MARDI GRAS



§ 114.15  ANNUAL EVENT.



   The Chamber of Commerce, as agent for and under the authority of the
City Council, Illinois, shall conduct the annual Halloween Mardi Gras
celebration on the last Friday and Saturday of October of each year.



(Ord. O-2000-19, passed 9-18-00)



§ 114.16  PARKING AND STREET CLOSURES.



   Street closures and limitations upon normal parking shall be as
determined by the City Council, and shall be enforced by the Police
Department with all necessary signs to be posted relative to any street
closures and parking restrictions.



(Ord. O-2000-19, passed 9-18-00)



§ 114.17  RULES AND REGULATIONS; FEES.



   The Chamber of Commerce is authorized to adopt rules and regulations
relative to entry fees for participation in parades and related events, fees
for participating in the flea market and for providing food and other
concession stands. All such fees must be paid to the Chamber of Commerce as a
condition precedent to a person, firm or corporation taking part in the
activity for which a fee is set. The Chamber of Commerce may also prescribe
forms acceptable to it for waiver of liability by participants, contracts for
participation and identifying badges for participants. The rules and
regulations adopted by the Chamber of Commerce shall be submitted to the City
Council for approval and shall then be placed on file with the City Clerk and
the Police Department in order to be available for inspection by prospective
participants.



(Ord. O-2000-19, passed 9-18-00)



§ 114.18  PROHIBITED VEHICLES.



   Bicycles, three wheelers, scooters, motorcycles, all-terrain vehicles,
and similar means of locomotion and similar vehicles shall be banned from
participation in any of the activities of the Halloween Mardi Gras, except
for parades in which they are actual participants and duly authorized by the
Chamber of Commerce.



(Ord. O-2000-19, passed 9-18-00)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.19  HALLOWEEN TRICK OR TREATING.



   Halloween Trick or Treating shall take place in the city on one evening
only, the date and time of which shall be determined by the Council.



(Ord. O-2000-19, passed 9-18-00)

VIDEO GAMING ESTABLISHMENTS



§ 114.35  DEFINITIONS.



   All terms and phrases used herein shall have the same meaning as
ascribed to them in the Illinois Video Gaming Act (ILCS Ch. 230, Act 40, §§
1 et seq.).



(Ord. O-2017-03, passed 3-27-17)



§ 114.36  SUPPLEMENTAL VIDEO GAMING LICENSE REQUIRED.



   (A)   Any establishment within the City of Pinckneyville which holds
a liquor license and has obtained a license to operate a video gaming
terminal from the Illinois Gaming Board at such premises (licensed
establishment) shall be required to apply for and obtain by May 1, 2017, a
supplemental video gaming license for the establishment from the City of
Pinckneyville.



   (B)   No licensed establishment shall operate a video gaming
terminal after May 1, 2017, without having obtained a license and video
gaming terminal sticker for each video gaming terminal from the City of
Pinckneyville pursuant to the license application procedures of this
subchapter.



   (C)   A license application form is attached to the ordinance
codified herein as Exhibit A. Applicants for a license shall submit a
completed license application form together with payment of the initial
annual license fee as calculated under the terms of this subchapter. The
Mayor is hereby authorized to investigate and verify the information shown in
the license application and approve, deny or return as incomplete any license
application. The Mayor shall take action upon each license application within
30 days after receipt of the application.



   (D)   The fee for a supplemental video gaming establishment license
shall be in the amount of  $25 per license year for each video gaming
terminal in the licensed establishment. The license year shall be from May 1
through April 30, commencing with an initial license year beginning May 1,
2017. The license fees shall not be prorated or refunded.



   (E)   Video gaming terminals may not be operated on any premises
that is located within 100 feet of a school or a place of worship.



   (F)   There shall not be more than five video gamine terminals at
any licensed establishment.



   (G)   Video gaming terminals must only be located in an area that is
restricted to persons to persons over 21 years of age. The entrance to such
area must be within the view of at least one employee.



   (H)   No licensee may cause or permit any person under the age of 21
years to use or play a video gaming terminal.



   (I)   Each licensed establishment that desires to operate a video
gaming terminal must possess a valid liquor license issued by the Illinois
Liquor Control Commission and the City of Pinckneyville.



   (J)   Those establishments that are licensed establishments,
licensed fraternal establishments and licensed veterans establishments, all
pursuant to the Video Gaming Act, may operate video gaming terminals only
during the hours of operation for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at
that establishment.



   (K)   Every licensed establishment shall comply with all provisions
of the Video Gaming Act and all rules, regulations, and restrictions imposed
by the Illinois Gaming Board.



(Ord. O-2017-03, passed 3-27-17)  Penalty, see § 114.99



§ 114.99  PENALTY.



   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined
not less than $100 or more than $750 for each offense.



(Ord. O-2000-14, passed 7-3-00; Ord. O-2000-19, passed 9-18-00; Am. Ord.
O-2013-08, passed 10-28-13; Am. Ord. O-2017-03, passed 3-27-17)



CHAPTER 115:  SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES
